{
  "article_text": [
    "a weak perturbation of a hamiltonian system causes the onset of chaotic layers around separatrices of the unperturbed system and/or separatrices surrounding nonlinear resonances generated by the perturbation @xcite .",
    "the system may be transported along the layer in a random - like fashion and this chaotic transport plays an important role in many physical phenomena @xcite . if the perturbation is sufficiently weak , then the layers are thin and the chaos is called _ local _ @xcite",
    ". as the perturbation magnitude increases , the width of the layer grows and the layers corresponding to adjacent separatrices reconnect at some , typically non - small , critical value of the perturbation .",
    "this conventionally marks the onset of _ global _ chaos @xcite i.e. chaos in a large region of the phase space , with chaotic transport throughout the whole relevant energy range .",
    "the reconnection of the layers around separatrices of the resonances often correlates with the overlap in energy between neighbouring resonances calculated independently in the resonant approximation .",
    "the latter constitutes the heuristic chirikov resonance - overlap criterion @xcite .",
    "but the chirikov criterion may fail if the system is of the _ zero - dispersion _ ( zd )",
    "type @xcite i.e. if the frequency of eigenoscillations possesses a local maximum or minimum as a function of its energy ( cf . also studies of related maps @xcite which are called _ nontwist _ , _ twistless _ or _ nonmonotonic twist _ maps ) . in such systems , there are typically two resonances of one and the same order @xcite , and their overlap in energy does not result in the onset of global chaos @xcite . even their overlap in phase space @xcite results typically only in the reconnection of the thin chaotic layers associated with the resonances .",
    "as the amplitude of the time - periodic perturbation grows further , the layers may _ separate _",
    "again @xcite .",
    "an example of the evolution of resonances in the plane of energy and slow angle is given in fig .",
    "1 ( the typical evolution of a real poincar section is shown e.g. in @xcite ) .",
    "as it is known @xcite , any hamiltonian system with two or more separatrices belongs to the zd type : the eigenfrequency as a function of energy possesses a local maximum between each pair of adjacent separatrices . for the purpose of global chaos onset",
    ", our letter @xcite has addressed the possibility to combine the overlap of resonances with each other ( typical of zd systems ) and their overlap with the chaotic layers associated with the separatrices . via numerical simulations , @xcite demonstrated that this is possible , leading to a scenario for global chaos onset which requires much smaller perturbation amplitudes than in the conventional case .",
    "the letter @xcite suggested also a heuristic theory for this effect ( more details were presented in @xcite ) .",
    "the _ present _ work develops the method for the quantitative description of chaotic layers in _ phase space _",
    ", for the resonance frequency range .",
    "we uncover the physical mechanism of their overlap with the resonances , and on this basis develop a detailed _ self - contained _ theory of the facilitated onset of global chaos .",
    "we also discuss generalizations and applications .",
    "the method for the description of the chaotic layers is of _ general importance _ : in conventional systems with a single - separatrix layer , it predicts a much larger maximum width in energy than what was assumed before @xcite .",
    "the paper is organized as follows . sec .",
    "ii introduces some relevant model example and presents the major results of the simulations : studying numerically the frequency dependence of the minimal amplitude of the ac drive for which global chaos occurs , @xmath0 , we show that @xmath0 possesses deep spikes at certain frequencies . sec .",
    "iii gives the self - consistent asymptotic theory for the minima of the spikes , after assessing the boundaries of the relevant chaotic layers .",
    "iv gives the theory for the spikes wings .",
    "discussion of a few generalizations and applications is carried out in sec .",
    "v. conclusions are drawn in sec .",
    "the appendix describes in details the new method for the analysis of separatrix chaos .",
    "as an example of a one - dimensional hamiltonian system possessing two or more separatrices , we use a spatially periodic potential system with two different - height barriers per period ( fig .",
    "2(a ) ) :    @xmath1    this model may relate e.g. to a pendulum spinning about its vertical axis @xcite or to a classical 2d electron gas in a magnetic field spatially periodic in one of the in - plane dimensions @xcite .",
    "the interest to the latter system arose in the 90th due to technological advances allowing to manufacture magnetic superlattices of high - quality @xcite leading to a variety of interesting behaviours of the charge carriers in semiconductors @xcite .",
    "2(b ) and 2(c ) show respectively the separatrices of the hamiltonian system ( 1 ) in the @xmath2 plane and the dependence of the frequency @xmath3 of its oscillation , often called _ eigenfrequency _ , on its energy @xmath4 .",
    "the separatrices correspond to energies equal to the value of the potential barrier tops @xmath5 and @xmath6 ( fig .",
    "the function @xmath7 is close to the extreme eigenfrequency @xmath8 for most of the range @xmath9 $ ] while sharply decreasing to zero as @xmath10 approaches either @xmath11 or @xmath12 .",
    "0.2 cm 0.2 cm 0.2 cm    add now a time - periodic perturbation : as an example , we use an ac drive , which corresponds to a dipole @xcite perturbation of the hamiltonian : @xmath13    the _ conventional _ scenario of global chaos onset between the separatrices of the system ( 2)-(1 ) is illustrated by fig .  3 .",
    "the figure presents the evolution of the stroboscopic poincar section as @xmath14 grows while @xmath15 is fixed at an arbitrarily chosen value _ away _ from @xmath16 and its harmonics . at small @xmath14 , there are two thin chaotic layers around the inner and outer separatrices of the unperturbed system .",
    "unbounded chaotic transport takes place only in the outer chaotic layer i.e.  in a _ narrow _ energy range .",
    "as @xmath14 grows , so do also the layers . at some critical value @xmath17 , the layers merge .",
    "this may be considered as the onset of global chaos : the whole range of energies between the barrier levels is involved , with unbounded chaotic transport .",
    "the states @xmath18 and @xmath19 ( where @xmath20 is any integer ) in the poincar section are associated respectively with the inner and outer saddles of the unperturbed system , and necessarily belong to the inner and outer chaotic layers , respectively .",
    "thus , the necessary and sufficient condition for global chaos onset may be formulated as the possibility for the system placed initially in the state @xmath21 to pass beyond the neighbouring of the outer ",
    "states , @xmath22 or @xmath23 , i.e. the coordinate @xmath24 becomes @xmath25 or @xmath26 at sufficiently large times @xmath27 .    a diagram in the @xmath28 plane , based on the above criterion , is shown in fig .",
    "the lower boundary of the shaded area represents the function @xmath29 .",
    "it has deep _ spikes _ i.e. cusp - like local minima .",
    "the most pronounced spikes are situated at frequencies @xmath30 that are slightly less than the odd multiples of @xmath16 ,    @xmath31    the deepest minimum occurs at @xmath32 : the value of @xmath33 in the minimum , @xmath34 , is approximately 40 times smaller than the value in the neighbouring pronounced local maximum of @xmath29 at @xmath35 . as @xmath36 increases",
    ", the @xmath36th minimum becomes less deep .",
    "the function @xmath29 is very sensitive to @xmath15 in the vicinity of the minima : for example , a shift of @xmath15 down from @xmath37 by only 1% causes an increase of @xmath33 by @xmath38 .",
    "the origin of the spikes becomes more clear looking at the evolution of the poincar section for @xmath39 as @xmath14 grows ( fig .",
    "5 ) : it drastically differs from the conventional evolution shown in fig .",
    "3 . for @xmath40 ( fig .  5(a ) ) , one can see four chaotic trajectories .",
    "two of them are associated with the inner and outer separatrices of the unperturbed system , similarly to the conventional case ( cf .",
    "they are marked by green and blue respectively .",
    "these trajectories fill the corresponding chaotic layers , which will be referred below as the inner `` and outer '' separatrix layers respectively .",
    "the other two chaotic trajectories marked by red and cyan are associated with the two nonlinear resonances of the 1st order .",
    "examples of non - chaotic trajectories separating the chaotic ones are shown in brown .",
    "as the perturbation amplitude @xmath14 increases , the outer separatrix layer sequentially absorbs other chaotic trajectories while large stability islands ( associated with the resonances ) arise in the layer . at @xmath41 ,",
    "it has absorbed the red trajectory : the resulting chaotic layer is shown in blue in fig .",
    "5(b ) . at @xmath42 ,",
    "this chaotic layer has absorbed the cyan chaotic trajectory : the resulting chaotic layer is shown in blue in fig .",
    "5(c ) @xcite .",
    "finally , at @xmath43 the latter blue layer has merged with the inner separatrix layer @xcite ( see fig .",
    "5(d ) ) , i.e. the onset of global chaos as defined above has occurred .    even prior to the theoretical analysis",
    ", one can draw a few conclusions from the evolution .",
    "namely , if @xmath15 is close to the minimum of the spike of @xmath29 , then    * the onset of global chaos occurs due to the _ combination _ of the overlap of chaotic layers associated with nonlinear resonances with each other and the overlap of the latter layers with the inner and outer separatrix layers ; * the width of the nonlinear resonances are large already at quite _ small _ amplitudes of the perturbation , so that the overlap with the chaotic layers around the original separatrices occurs at unusually small perturbation amplitudes ; * the onset of the overlap of at least one of the nonlinear resonances with the outer separatrix layer occurs at values of @xmath14 which are a few times smaller than those required for the onset of the overlap with the inner separatrix layer .",
    "the above conclusions are also illustrated by fig .",
    "6 which presents the evolution of the phase space of slow variables @xcite , action @xmath44 and slow angle @xmath45 , calculated in resonance approximation for the 1st - order spike ( see eq . ( 4 ) below ) .    similarly , for the spikes of higher order , higher - order resonances are relevant",
    "the eigenfrequency @xmath7 is close to its local maximum @xmath16 for most of the relevant range @xmath9 $ ] ( fig .",
    "as shown below , @xmath7 approaches a _ rectangular _ form in the asymptotic limit @xmath46 .",
    "hence , if the perturbation frequency @xmath47 is close to @xmath16 or its odd multiples , @xmath48 , then the energy width of nonlinear resonances becomes comparable to the width of the whole range between barriers ( i.e. @xmath49 ) at a rather small perturbation magnitude @xmath50 .",
    "note that @xmath51 determines the characteristic magnitude of the perturbation required for the conventional overlap of the separatrix chaotic layers , when @xmath15 is not close to any odd multiple of @xmath52 ( fig .",
    "3 ( c ) ) . thus ,",
    "if @xmath53 , the nonlinear resonances should play a crucial role in the onset of global chaos ( cf .",
    "fig . 5 ) .",
    "we note that it is not entirely obvious _ a priori _ whether it is indeed possible to calculate @xmath54 within the resonance approximation : in fact , it is essential for the separatrices of nonlinear resonances to nearly touch the barriers levels , but the resonance approximation is obviously invalid in the close vicinity of the barriers ; furthermore , numerical calculations of resonances show that , if @xmath55 , the perturbation amplitude @xmath14 at which the resonance separatrix touches a given energy level in the close vicinity of the barriers is very sensitive to @xmath15 , apparently making the calculation of @xmath56 within the resonance approximation even less feasible .",
    "nevertheless , we show below in a self - consistent manner that , in the asymptotic limit @xmath57 , the relevant boundaries of the chaotic layers lie in the range of energies @xmath10 where @xmath58 .",
    "therefore , the resonant approximation is valid and it allows to obtain _ explicit _ asymptotic expressions both for @xmath59 and @xmath56 , and for the wings of the spikes in the vicinities of @xmath60 .",
    "the _ asymptotic _",
    "limit @xmath57 is the most interesting one from a theoretical point of view since this limit leads to the strongest facilitation of the global chaos onset and it is most accurately described by the self - contained theory .",
    "most of the theory presented below assumes this limit and concentrates therefore on the results to the _ lowest _ order in the small parameter . on the applications side ,",
    "the range of _ moderately small _",
    "@xmath61 is more interesting , since the chaos facilitation is still pronounced ( and still described by the asymptotic theory ) while the area of chaos between the separatrices is not too small ( comparable with the area inside the inner separatrix ) : cf .",
    "figs . 2 , 3 and 5 . to increase the accuracy of the theoretical description in this range",
    ", we estimate the next - order corrections and develop an efficient numerical procedure allowing for the further corrections .",
    "let @xmath15 be close to the @xmath36th odd @xcite harmonic of @xmath16 , @xmath62 .",
    "over most of the range @xmath9 $ ] , except in the close vicinities of @xmath11 and @xmath12 , the @xmath36th harmonic of eigenoscillation is nearly resonant with the perturbation . due to this ,",
    "the ( slow ) dynamics of the action @xmath63 and the angle @xmath64 @xcite can be shown to be described by the following auxiliary hamiltonian ( cf .",

    "the system stays most of the time very close to one of the barriers .",

    "we emphasize that @xmath112 determines the strength  of the nonlinear resonances : therefore , apart from the nearly rectangular form of @xmath7 , * the non - smallness of @xmath112 is one more factor giving rise to the strong facilitation of the global chaos onset*.    we shall need also the asymptotic expression of the action @xmath113 . substituting @xmath7 ( 7 ) into the definition of @xmath114 ( 4 ) and carrying out the integration , we obtain    @xmath115      we now turn to the analysis of the _ phase space _ of the resonance hamiltonian ( 4 ) . the evolution of the poincar section ( see fig . 5 and the related analysis in sec .",
    "ii ) suggests that we need to find such _ separatrix _ of ( 4 ) which undergoes the following evolution as @xmath14 grows : for sufficiently small @xmath14 , the separatrix does not overlap chaotic layers associated with the barriers while , for @xmath116 , it does overlap them .",
    "the relevance of such a condition will be justified further .",
    "for @xmath117 with a given odd @xmath36 , the equations of motion of the system ( 4 ) read as follows    @xmath118    any separatrix necessarily includes one or more unstable stationary points .",
    "the system ( 14 ) may have several stationary points per @xmath119 interval of @xmath120 .",
    "let us first exclude those points which are irrelevant to the separatrix undergoing the evolution described above .",
    "given that @xmath121 , there are two unstable stationary points with @xmath113 corresponding to @xmath122 and @xmath123 .",
    "they are irrelevant since , even for an infinitely small @xmath14 , each of them necessarily lies inside the corresponding barrier chaotic layer .    if @xmath124 , then @xmath125 , so @xmath126 only if @xmath120 is equal either to 0 or to @xmath127 .",
    "substituting these values into the second equation of ( 14 ) and putting @xmath128 , we obtain the equations for the corresponding actions :    @xmath129    where the signs - `` and + '' correspond to @xmath130 and @xmath131 respectively .",
    "a typical example of the graphic solution of equations ( 15 ) for @xmath132 is shown in fig .",
    "two of the roots corresponding to @xmath131 are very close to the barrier values of @xmath113 ( we remind that the relevant values of @xmath14 are small ) .",
    "these roots arise due to the divergence of @xmath133 as @xmath113 approaches any of the barrier values .",
    "the lower / upper root corresponds to a stable / unstable point .",
    "however , for any @xmath36 , both these points and the separatrix generated by the unstable point necessarily lie in the ranges covered by the barrier chaotic layers .",
    "therefore , they are also irrelevant @xcite . for @xmath134 , the number of the roots of ( 15 ) in the vicinity of the barriers may be larger ( due to the oscillations of the modulus and sign of @xmath135 in the vicinity of the barriers ) but they all are irrelevant for the same reason , at least to leading - order terms in the expressions for the spikes minima .",
    "consider the stationary points corresponding to the remaining four roots of equations ( 15 ) . as follows from the analysis of equations ( 14 ) linearized near the stationary points ( cf .",
    "@xcite ) , two of them are stable elliptic points @xcite , often called _ nonlinear resonances _ , while two others are unstable hyperbolic points , often called _",
    "saddles_. these saddles are of main interest in the context of our work .",
    "they belong to the _ separatrices _ separating the regions of oscillations around the resonances from the regions of motion with a running  slow angle @xmath120 .",
    "we shall distinguish the relevant saddles as the saddles with the _ lower _ action / energy ( using the subscript @xmath136  ) and _ upper _ action / energy ( using the subscript @xmath137  ) .",
    "the positions of the saddles in the @xmath138 plane are defined by the following equations ( cf . figs . 6 and 7 ) :    @xmath139 } , \\\\ & & \\tilde{\\psi}_{sl}=\\pi(1+g)/2 , \\quad\\quad \\tilde{\\psi}_{su}=\\pi(1-g)/2,\\nonumber \\\\ & & x_g(i_{sl})=x_{-g}(i_{su})=0 , \\nonumber \\\\ & & \\frac { { \\rm d}x_g(i_{sl})}{{\\rm d}i_{sl}}>0 , \\quad\\quad \\frac { { \\rm d}x_{-g}(i_{su})}{{\\rm d}i_{su}}<0 , \\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    where @xmath140 are defined in eq .",
    "( 15 ) while @xmath141 and @xmath142 are closer to @xmath143 than any other solution of ( 16 ) ( if any ) from below and from above , respectively .",
    "given that the values of @xmath14 relevant to the minima of the spikes are small in the asymptotic limit @xmath57 , one may neglect the last term in the definition of @xmath144 in eq .",
    "( 15 ) in the lowest - order approximation , so that the equations @xmath145 reduce to the simple resonance condition    @xmath146    substituting here eq .",

    "ii ) and as it is rigorously shown in the next subsection , one of the main conditions which should be satisfied in the spikes is the overlap in phase space between the separatrices of the nonlinear resonances , called _ separatrix reconnection _ @xcite . given that the hamiltonian @xmath153 is constant along any trajectory of the system ( 4 ) , the values of @xmath153 in the lower and upper saddles of the _ reconnected _ separatrices are equal to each other :    @xmath154    that may be considered as the necessary and sufficient @xcite condition for the reconnection .",
    "taking into account that @xmath155 ( see ( 19 ) ) , it follows from ( 20 ) that    @xmath156    explicitly , the relations in ( 21 ) reduce to @xmath157 , \\nonumber \\\\ & & \\delta e^{(1)}\\equiv \\sqrt{\\phi^2 - 64\\exp(-\\frac{n\\pi}{\\omega_f } ) } , \\\\ & & 0<\\omega_m-\\omega_f / n\\ll \\omega_m\\equiv \\frac{\\pi}{2\\ln(8/\\phi ) } , \\nonumber \\\\ & & n=1,3,5 , ... \\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    the function @xmath158 ( 22 ) monotonously decreases to zero as @xmath15 grows from @xmath159 to @xmath160 , where the line abruptly stops .",
    "10 shows the portions of the lines ( 22 ) relevant to the left wings of the 1st and 2nd spikes ( for @xmath161 ) .      the next step is to find a minimal value of @xmath14 for which the resonance separatrix overlaps the chaotic layer related to a potential barrier . with this aim ,",
    "we study how the relevant outer boundary of the chaotic layer behaves as @xmath14 and @xmath15 vary .",
    "assume that the relevant @xmath15 is close to @xmath160 while the relevant @xmath14 is sufficiently large for @xmath7 to be close to @xmath16 at all points of the outer boundary of the layer ( the results will confirm these assumptions ) .",
    "then the motion along the regular trajectory infinitesimally close to the layer boundary may be described within the resonance approximation ( 4 ) .",
    "hence the boundary may also be described as a trajectory of the resonant hamiltonian ( 4 ) .",
    "this is explicitly proved in the appendix , using the separatrix map analysis that allows for the validity of the relation @xmath58 for all @xmath10 relevant to the boundary of the chaotic layer .",
    "the main results are presented below . for the sake of clarity",
    ", we present them for each layer separately , although they are similar in practice .",
    "let @xmath15 be close to any of the spikes minima .",
    "one of the key roles in the formation of the upper boundary of the layer is played by the angle - dependent quantity @xmath162 which we call the _ generalized separatrix split _ ( gss ) for the lower layer , alluding to the conventional _ separatrix split _ @xcite for the lower layer @xmath163 with @xmath164 given by eq .",
    "( a11 ) @xcite .",
    "accordingly , we use the term lower gss curve  for the following curve in the @xmath138 plane :    @xmath165    0.2 cm    2.5 cm _",
    "a. relatively small @xmath14 _    0.2 cm    if @xmath166 , where the critical value @xmath167 is determined by eq .",
    "( 41 ) ( its origin will be explained further ) , then there are differences in the boundary formation for the frequency ranges of _ odd _ and _ even _ spikes .",

    "( [ 27 ] ) yields the following expression for the minimal deviation of energy on the boundary from the barrier : @xmath178    in the context of global chaos onset , the most important property of the boundary is that the _ maximal _ deviation of its energy from the barrier , @xmath179 , greatly exceeds both @xmath180 and @xmath181 . as @xmath182 , the maximum of the boundary approaches the saddle  .",
    "0.2 cm    2.9 cm _ a.2 . even spikes _    0.2 cm    in this case , the hamiltonian ( 4 ) possesses saddles  in the close vicinity to the lower barrier ( see fig .",
    "their angles differ by @xmath127 from those of  :",
    "@xmath183}}{2}+2\\pi m , \\\\ & & m=0,\\pm 1 , \\pm 2 , \\ldots , \\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    while the deviation of their energies from the barrier still lies in the relevant ( resonant ) range and reads , in the lowest - order approximation ,    @xmath184    the lower whiskers of the separatrix generated by these saddles intersect the gss curve while the upper whiskers in the asymptotic limit do not intersect it ( fig .",
    "thus , it is the upper whiskers of the separatrix which form the boundary of the chaotic layer in the asymptotic limit .",
    "the energy on the boundary takes the minimal value right on the saddle  , so that    @xmath185    similar to the case of the odd spikes , the _ maximal _ ( along the boundary ) deviation of the energy from the barrier greatly exceeds both @xmath180 and @xmath181 . as @xmath182 , the maximum of the boundary approaches the saddle  .    0.2 cm    2.9 cm _",
    "b. relatively large @xmath14 _    0.2 cm    if @xmath186 , the previously described trajectory ( the tangent one or the separatrix , for the odd or even spike ranges respectively ) is encompassed by the separatrix of the lower nonlinear resonance and typically forms the boundary of the major stability island inside the lower layer ( reproduced periodically in @xmath120 with the period @xmath119 ) .",
    "the upper _ outer _ boundary of the layer is formed by the upper part of the _ resonance separatrix_. this may be interpreted as the absorption of the lower resonance by the lower chaotic layer .",
    "0.75 cm 0.75 cm      let @xmath15 be close to any of the spikes minima .",

    "thus , it is the lower whiskers of the separatrix which form the boundary of the chaotic layer in the asymptotic limit .",

    "_ b. relatively large @xmath14 _    0.2 cm    if @xmath210 ( cf .",
    "8(a ) ) , the previously described trajectory ( tangent one or the separatrix , for the even and odd spikes ranges respectively ) is encompassed by the separatrix of the upper nonlinear resonance and typically forms the boundary of the major stability island inside the upper layer ( reproduced periodically in @xmath120 with the period @xmath119 ) .",
    "the lower _",
    "outer _ boundary of the layer is formed in this case by the lower part of the _ resonance separatrix_. this may be interpreted as the absorption of the upper resonance by the upper chaotic layer .",
    "0.5 cm    the description of chaotic layers given above and , in more details , in the appendix is the * first main result of this paper*. it provides a _ rigorous base _ for our intuitive assumption that the minimal value of @xmath14 at which the layers overlap corresponds to the reconnection of the nonlinear resonances with each other while the reconnected resonances touch one of the layers and touch / overlap another layer .",
    "it is remarkable also that we have managed to obtain the _ quantitative _ theoretical description of the chaotic layers boundaries in the _ phase space _ , including even the major stability islands , that well fits the results of simulations ( see fig .",
    "8(b ) ) .",
    "the condition for the merger of the lower resonance and the lower chaotic layer may be written as    @xmath211    the condition for the merger of the upper resonance and the upper chaotic layer may be written as    @xmath212    for the global chaos onset related to the spike minimum , either of eqs . ( 41 ) and ( 42 ) should be combined with the condition of the separatrix reconnection ( 20 ) .",
    "let us seek first only the leading terms of @xmath213 and @xmath214 .",
    "then ( 20 ) may be replaced by its lowest - order approximation ( 21 ) or , equivalently , ( 22 ) .",

    "the solution @xmath219 of the system of equations ( 22),(43 ) and the solution @xmath220 of the system of equations ( 22),(44 ) turn out _ identical _ to the _ leading _ order . for the sake of brevity",
    ", we derive below just @xmath219 , denoting the latter , in short , as @xmath221 @xcite .",
    "the system of algebraic equations ( 22 ) and ( 43 ) is still too complicated to find its exact solution .",
    "however , we need only the _ lowest - order _ solution - and this simplifies the problem . still , even this simplified problem is not trivial , both because the function @xmath222 turns out to be non - analytic and because @xmath223 in ( 22 ) is very sensitive to @xmath15 in the relevant range . despite these difficulties",
    ", we have found the solution in a _ self - consistent _ way , as briefly described below .",
    "assume that the asymptotic dependence @xmath224 is :    @xmath225    where the constant @xmath226 may be found from the asymptotic solution of ( 22 ) , ( 43 ) , ( 45 ) .",

    "4 ) :    @xmath247    the values by the lowest - order formula ( 52 ) are :    @xmath248    the theoretical value @xmath249 gives a reasonable estimate for the simulation value @xmath250 .",
    "the theoretical value @xmath251 gives the correct order of magnitude for the simulation value @xmath252 .",
    "thus , the accuracy of the lowest - order formula ( 52 ) for @xmath234 is much lower than that for @xmath253 : this is due to the steepness of @xmath0 in the ranges of spikes ( the steepness , in turn , is due to the flatness of the function @xmath7 near its maximum ) .",
    "moreover , as the number of the spike @xmath254 increases , the accuracy of the lowest - order value @xmath255 significantly decreases .",
    "the latter can be explained as follows . for the next - order correction to @xmath255 ,",
    "the dependence on @xmath61 reads as :    @xmath256    at least some of the terms of this correction are positive and proportional to @xmath255 ( e.g. due to the difference between the exact equation ( 15 ) and its approximate version ( 17 ) ) while @xmath255 is proportional to @xmath257 .",
    "thus , for @xmath161 , the relative correction for the 1st spike is @xmath258 while the correction for the 2nd spike is a few times larger i.e. @xmath259 .",
    "but the latter means that , for @xmath161 , the asymptotic theory for the 2nd spike can not pretend to be a quantitative description of @xmath260 , but only provide the correct order of magnitude . besides , if @xmath134 while @xmath61 exceeds some critical value , then the search of the minimum involves eq .",
    "( 66 ) rather than eq .",
    "( 20 ) , as explained below in sec .",
    "10(b ) and 11 ) .",
    "altogether , this explains why @xmath250 is larger than @xmath249 only by 50@xmath261 while @xmath252 is larger than @xmath251 by 200@xmath261 .",
    "the consistent explicit derivation of the correction to @xmath255 is complicated .",

    "the numerical solution described above gives :    @xmath268    the agreement with the simulation results is : ( i ) excellent for @xmath269 for the both spikes and for @xmath234 for the 1st spike , ( ii ) reasonable for @xmath234 for the 2nd spike .",
    "thus , if @xmath61 is _ moderately _ small , a much more accurate prediction for @xmath234 than that by the lowest - order formula is provided by the numerical procedure described above .",
    "the goal of this section is to find mechanisms responsible for the formation of the spikes _ wings _",
    "( i.e. the function @xmath0 in the ranges of @xmath15 slightly deviating from @xmath60 ) and to provide for their theoretical description . before developing the theory , we briefly analyze the simulation data ( fig .",
    "4 ) , concentrating on the 1st spike .",
    "the left wing of the spike is smooth and nearly straight .",
    "the initial part of the right wing is also nearly straight @xcite though less steep .",
    "but , at some small distance from @xmath270 , its slope changes jump - wise by a few times : compare the derivative @xcite @xmath271 at @xmath15 slightly exceeding @xmath37 ( see the left inset in fig .",
    "4 ) and @xmath272 at @xmath273 ( see the main part of fig .",
    ", even prior to the theoretical analysis , one may assume that there are a few different important mechanisms responsible for the formation of the wings .",
    "consider the arbitrary @xmath254th spike .",
    "we have shown in the previous section that , in the asymptotic limit @xmath57 , the minimum of the spike corresponds to the intersection between the lines ( 20 ) and ( 41)/(42 ) for odd / even spikes .",
    "we recall that : ( i ) eq . ( 20 ) corresponds to the overlap in phase space between nonlinear resonances of the same order @xmath257 ; ( ii ) eq . ( 41)/(42 ) corresponds to the onset of the overlap between the resonance separatrix associated with the lower / upper saddle and the chaotic layer associated with the lower / upper potential barrier ; ( iii ) for @xmath30 , the condition ( 41)/(42 ) guarantees also the overlap between the upper / lower resonance separatrix and the chaotic layer associated with the upper / lower barrier @xcite .",
    "0.75 cm 0.75 cm 0.75 cm    if @xmath15 becomes slightly smaller than @xmath60 the resonances shift closer to the barriers while moving apart from each other .",
    "hence , as @xmath14 increases , the overlap of the resonances with the chaotic layers associated with the barriers occurs earlier than with each other .",
    "therefore , at @xmath274 , the function @xmath0 should approximately correspond to the reconnection of resonances of the order @xmath275 ( fig .",
    "9(a ) ) . fig .",
    "10(a ) demonstrates that even the asymptotic formula ( 22 ) for the separatrix reconnection line fits the left wing of the 1st spike quite well while the numerically calculated line ( 20 ) agrees with the simulations perfectly .    if @xmath15 becomes slightly larger than @xmath60 then , on the contrary , the resonances shift closer to each other and more far from the barriers .",
    "therefore , the overlap of resonances with each other occurs at smaller @xmath14 than the overlap between any of them and the chaotic layer associated with the lower / upper barrier ( cf . figs .",
    "5(c ) and 5(d ) as well as 6(c ) and 6(d ) ) .",
    "hence , it is the latter overlap which determines the function @xmath0 in the relevant range of @xmath15 ( fig .",
    "9(b ) ) . fig .",
    "10 shows that @xmath0 is indeed well approximated in the close vicinity to the right from @xmath60 by the numerical solution of eq .",
    "( 41)/(42 ) for an odd / even spike and , for the 1st spike and the given @xmath61 , even by its asymptotic form ,    @xmath276 } { 2\\sqrt{2 } } , \\\\ & & \\delta e^{(1)}\\equiv \\sqrt{\\phi^2 - 64\\exp(-\\frac{n\\pi}{\\omega_f } ) } , \\nonumber \\\\ & & n\\equiv 2j-1,\\quad |\\omega_f-\\omega_s^{(j)}|\\ll \\omega_m \\ , , \\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    0.75 cm    the mechanism described above determines @xmath0 only in the close vicinity of @xmath60 .",
    "if @xmath277 becomes too close to @xmath16 or exceeds it , then the resonances are not of immediate relevance : they may even disappear or , if they still exist , their closed loops shrink , so that they can not anymore provide for the connection of the chaotic layers in the relevant range of @xmath14 .",
    "at the same time , the closeness of the frequency to @xmath16 still may give rise to a large variation of action along the trajectory of the hamiltonian system ( 4 ) . for the odd / even spikes , the boundaries of the chaotic layers in the asymptotic limit @xmath57 are formed in this case by the trajectory of ( 4 ) which is tangent to the lower / upper gss curves ( for the lower / upper layer ) or by the lower / upper part of the separatrix of ( 4 ) generated by the saddle @xmath278/@xmath279 ",
    "( for the upper / lower layer ) .",
    "obviously , the overlap of the layers occurs when these trajectories coincide with each other , that may be formulated as the equality of @xmath153 in the corresponding tangency and saddle :    @xmath280    note however that , for _ moderately _ small @xmath61 , the tangencies may be relevant both to the lower layer and to the upper one ( see the appendix ) .",
    "indeed , such a case occurs for our example with @xmath161 : see fig .",
    "therefore , the overlap of the layers corresponds to the equality of @xmath153 in the tangencies :    @xmath281    to the lowest order , eq .",
    "( 63 ) and eq .",
    "( 64 ) read as :    @xmath282    both the line ( 64 ) and the asymptotic line ( 65 ) well agree with the part of the right wing of the 1st spike situated beyond the immediate vicinity of the minimum from the right side , namely , to the right from the fold at @xmath283 ( fig .",
    "the fold corresponds to the change of the mechanisms of the chaotic layers overlap",
    ".    if @xmath61 is moderately small while @xmath134 , the description of the far wings by the numerical lines ( 20 ) and ( 64 ) may be still quite good but the asymptotic lines ( 22 ) and ( 65 ) can not pretend to describe the wings quantitatively anymore ( fig .",
    "10(b ) ) . as for",
    "the very minimum of the spike and the wings in the close vicinity to it , one more mechanism may become relevant for their formation in this case ( figs .",
    "10(b ) and 11 ) .",
    "this mechanism may be explained as follows . if @xmath134 , then @xmath151 becomes zero in the close vicinity ( @xmath284 ) of the relevant barrier ( the upper / lower barrier , in the case of even / odd spikes : cf .",
    "as follows from the equations of motion ( 14 ) , no trajectory can cross the line @xmath285 . in the asymptotic limit @xmath57 ,",
    "provided @xmath14 is from the relevant range , almost the whole gss curve is farer from the barrier than the line @xmath285 , and the latter becomes irrelevant .",
    "but , for a moderately small @xmath61 , the line may separate the whole gss curve from the rest of the phase space .",
    "then the resonance separatrix can not connect to the gss curve even if there is a state on the latter curve with the same value of @xmath153 as on the resonance separatrix .",
    "for a given @xmath15 , the connection requires then a higher value of @xmath14 : for such a value , the gss curve itself crosses the line @xmath285 . in the relevant range of @xmath14 ,",
    "the resonance separatrix passes very close to this line , so that the connection is well approximated by the condition that the gss curve _ touches _ this line ( see the inset in fig . 11 ) :    @xmath286",
    "this mechanism is relevant for the formation of the minimum of the 2nd spike at @xmath161 , and in the close vicinity of the spike , on the left ( fig .",
    "10(b ) ) .    finally , let us explicitly find the _",
    "universal asymptotic shape _ of the spike in the vicinity of its minimum .",
    "first , we note that the lowest - order expression ( 62 ) for the spike between the minimum and the fold can be written as the _ half - sum _ of the expressions ( 22 ) and ( 65 ) ( which represent the lowest - order approximations for the spike to the left of the minimum , and to the right of the fold respectively ) .",
    "thus , all three lines ( 22 ) , ( 62 ) and ( 65 ) intersect in one point .",
    "the latter means that , in the asymptotic limit @xmath57 , the fold merges with the minimum : @xmath15 and @xmath14 in the fold asymptotically approach @xmath233 and @xmath234 respectively .",
    "thus , though the fold is a generic feature of the spikes , it is not of main significance : the spike is formed basically by two straight lines .",
    "the ratio between their slopes is universal .",
    "so , introducing a proper scaling , we reduce the spike shape to a universal function ( fig .",
    "12 ) :    @xmath287    where @xmath288 and @xmath244 are the lowest - order expressions ( 52 ) respectively for the frequency and amplitude in the spike minimum , @xmath289 is the expression ( 55 ) for the frequency in the spike minimum , including the first - order correction , and @xmath237 is the constant ( 51 ) .    beside the left and right wings of the universal shape ( the solid lines in fig .",
    "12 ) , we also present in ( 67 ) the function @xmath290 ( the dashed line in fig .",
    "12 ) : it purposes to show that , on one hand , the fold asymptotically merges with the minimum but , on the other hand , the fold is generic and the slope of the spike between the minimum and the fold has a universal ratio to any of the slopes of the major wings .    even for a moderately small @xmath61 , like in our example ,",
    "the ratios between the three slopes related to the 1st spike in the simulations are reasonably well reproduced by those in eq .",
    "( 67 ) : cf .",
    "10(a ) and 12 .",
    "it follows from ( 67 ) that the asymptotic scaled shape is universal i.e. independent of @xmath61 , @xmath36 or any other parameter .",
    "the description of the wings of the spikes near their minima , in particular the derivation of the spike universal shape , is the * third main result of this paper*.",
    "the _ new approach _ for the treatment of separatrix chaos opens a broad variety of important generalizations and applications , some of which are discussed below .    1 .",
    "it may be applied to _ any _ separatrix layer , including in particular the conventional _ single - separatrix _ case .",
    "this is possible due to the characteristic dependence of the frequency of eigenoscillation on energy in the vicinity of any separatrix : the frequency keeps nearly a _ constant _ value even if the deviation of the energy from the separatrix _ strongly varies _ within a given scale of the deviation .",
    "to the best of our knowledge , the latter idea was not exploited before , which is why probably it was thought to be impossible to analyze the dynamics of the separatrix map in an explicit form .",
    "there were various estimates of the layer width in energy ( see @xcite and references therein ) but the quantitative analysis of the layer boundaries in the _ phase space _ was never done in the non - adiabatic case .",
    "in contrast , our approach does analyze the dynamics of the separatrix map , and this allows us in particular to quantitatively describe the layer boundaries in case when the perturbation is resonant with the eigenoscillation in the relevant range of energy .",
    "it follows from such a description that , for a given small amplitude @xmath14 of the perturbation , the maximal layer width in energy is much larger than it is assumed by former theories ( cf .",
    "@xcite where the maximal width is assumed to be @xmath291 ) .",
    "thus , we can quantitatively describe large _ jumps _ and _ peaks _ of the layer width as a function of the perturbation amplitude and frequency respectively @xcite .",
    "moreover , a rough estimate on the basis of our approach indicates that , for many classes of systems , the relative range of such jumps / peaks ( i.e. the ratio between the upper and lower levels of the jump / peak ) _ diverges _ in the asymptotic limit @xmath292 .",
    "2 .   apart from the description of the boundaries , the approach allows us to describe the _",
    "chaotic transport _ within the layer .",
    "in particular , it may allow us to calculate a positive lyapunov exponent and to describe diffusion .",
    "our approach may be generalized for a _ non - resonant _ perturbation .",
    "the resonance approximation is not valid then but there still remains the property of a nearly constancy of the frequency of eigenoscillation within an arbitrary given scale of the deviation of energy from the separatrix .",
    "this property may allow us to explicitly describe the dynamics of the separatrix map for any frequency of perturbation which is less than or of the order of the resonance frequency .",
    "4 .   apart from hamiltonian systems of the one and a half degrees of freedom and corresponding zaslavsky separatrix maps",
    ", our approach may be useful in the treatment of other chaotic systems and separatrix maps ( see @xcite for the most recent major review on various types of separatrix maps and related continuous chaotic systems ) .",
    "as concerns the _ facilitation of the global chaos onset _ between adjacent separatrices , we mention the following generalizations :    * 1 .",
    "* the spikes in @xmath0 may occur for an _ arbitrary hamiltonian _ system with two or more separatrices .",
    "the asymptotic theory can be generalized accordingly .",
    "the absence of pronounced spikes at _ even _ harmonics @xmath293 is explained by the symmetry of the potential ( 1 ) : the even fourier harmonics of the coordinate , @xmath294 , are equal to zero . for time - periodic perturbation of dipole type , like in eq .",
    "( 2 ) , there are no resonances of even order due to this symmetry @xcite . if either the potential is _ non - symmetric _ or the additive perturbation of the hamiltonian is not an _ odd _ function of the coordinate , then even - order resonances do exist , resulting in the presence of the spikes in @xmath0 at @xmath295 .    * 3 .",
    "* there may be an additional facilitation of global chaos onset which is reasonable to call a secondary  facilitation .",
    "let the frequency @xmath15 be close to the frequency @xmath233 of the spike minimum while the amplitude @xmath14 be @xmath296 but still lower than @xmath0 .",
    "then there are two resonance separatrices in the @xmath138 plane which are not connected by the chaotic transport ( cf . fig .",
    "6(b ) and 5(b ) ) .",
    "this system possesses the zero - dispersion property .",
    "the trajectories of the resonant hamiltonian ( 4 ) which start in between the separatrices oscillate in @xmath113 ( as well as in @xmath297 ) .",
    "the frequency @xmath298 of such oscillations along a given trajectory depends on the corresponding value of @xmath153 analogously to as @xmath3 depends on @xmath10 for the original hamiltonian @xmath74 : @xmath299 is equal to zero for the values of @xmath153 corresponding to the separatrices ( being equal in turn to @xmath300 and @xmath301 : see eq .",
    "( 19 ) ) while possessing a nearly rectangular shape in between , provided the quantity @xmath302 is much smaller than the variation of @xmath153 within each of the resonances ,    @xmath303 and @xmath304 are the values of @xmath153 in the elliptic point of the lower and upper resonance respectively .",
    "the maximum of @xmath299 in between @xmath300 and @xmath301 is asymptotically described by the following formula :    @xmath305    if we additionally perturb the system in such a way that an additional time - periodic term of the frequency @xmath306 arises in the resonance hamiltonian , then the chaotic layers associated with the resonance separatrices may be connected by chaotic transport even for a rather small amplitude of the additional perturbation , due to a scenario similar to the one described in this paper",
    ".    there may be various types of such additional perturbation @xcite .",
    "for example , one may _ add _ to @xmath307 ( 2 ) one more dipole time - periodic perturbation of _ mixed _ frequency ( i.e. @xmath308 ) .",
    "alternatively , one may directly perturb the _ angle _ of the original perturbation by a _ low - frequency _ perturbation , i.e. the time - periodic term in @xmath307 ( 2 ) is replaced by the term    @xmath309    recent physical problems where a similar situation is relevant are : chaotic mixing and transport in a meandering jet flow @xcite and reflection of light rays in a corrugated waveguide @xcite .",
    "if the time - periodic perturbation is _ multiplicative _ rather than additive , the resonances become _ parametric _ ( cf.@xcite ) .",
    "parametric resonance is more complicated and much less studied than nonlinear resonance .",
    "nevertheless , the main mechanism for the onset of global chaos remains the same , namely the combination of the reconnection between resonances of the same order and of their overlap in energy with the chaotic layers associated with the barriers . at the same time , the frequencies of the main spikes in @xmath0 may change ( though still being related to @xmath16 ) .",
    "we consider below the example when the periodically driven parameter is the parameter @xmath61 in ( 1 ) @xcite .",
    "the hamiltonian reads as    @xmath310    the term @xmath311 in @xmath307 ( 71 ) may be rewritten as @xmath312 .",
    "the last term in the latter expression does not affect the equations of motion .",
    "thus , we end up with an additive perturbation @xmath313 . in the asymptotic limit @xmath314 , the @xmath36th - order fourier component of the function @xmath315",
    "can be shown to differ from zero only for the orders @xmath316 therefore one may expect the main spikes in @xmath0 to be at frequencies twice larger than those for the dipole perturbation ( 2 ) :    @xmath317    this well agrees with the results of simulations ( fig .",
    "13 ) .    moreover , the asymptotic theory for the dipole perturbation may be immediately generalized to the present case : it is necessary only to replace the fourier component of the coordinate @xmath24 by the fourier component of the function @xmath315 :    @xmath318    ( cf .",
    "( 12 ) for @xmath101 ) .",
    "we obtain :    @xmath319    where @xmath237 is given in eqs . ( 50 ) and ( 51 ) .    for @xmath320 ,",
    "( 74 ) gives , for the 1st spike , values differing from the simulation data by about @xmath321 for the frequency and by about @xmath322 for the amplitude .",
    "thus , the lowest - order formulas accurately describe the 1st spike even for a moderately small @xmath61 .",
    "one more generalization relates to _ multi - dimensional _ hamiltonian systems with two or more saddles with different energies : the perturbation may not necessarily be time - periodic , in this case . the detailed analysis will be done elsewhere .    finally , we point out some analogy between the facilitation of global chaos onset described in our work and the so called stochastic percolation in 2d hamiltonian systems described in @xcite : the merging of internal and external chaotic zones is also relevant there , like in our case . however , both the models and the underlying mechanisms are very different .",
    "namely , the problem studied in @xcite is not of the zero - dispersion type ; and the two - dimensionality is inherently important .",
    "let us turn now to a few detailed examples of applications of the facilitation of global chaos onset .",
    "the first application relates to a classical electron gas in a magnetic superlattice @xcite , where the electrons may be considered as non - interacting quasi - particles moving on a plane perpendicular to the magnetic field spatially periodic in one of the in - plane directions ( we denote it as @xmath323-direction ) .",
    "then the electron motion in the x - direction is described by the hamiltonian ( 1 ) in which @xmath24 and @xmath324 are the scaled electron coordinate @xmath323 and generalized momentum @xmath325 respectively , while the parameter @xmath61 is proportional to the reciprocal amplitude of the external magnetic field , @xmath326 , and to the generalized momentum @xmath327 in the second ( perpendicular to @xmath323 ) in - plane direction : see for details @xcite .",
    "note that @xmath327 remains constant during the motion @xcite .",
    "if an ac electric field is applied in the @xmath323-direction , then the model ( 2)-(1 ) becomes relevant .",
    "the _ dc - conductivity _ in the @xmath323-direction is proportional to the fraction of electrons that can take part to the unbounded motion in the @xmath323-direction .",
    "this fraction , in turn , significantly grows as the range of energies involved in the unbounded chaotic transport increases @xcite .",
    "if electrons move in vacuum @xcite , then it may be possible to inject a beam of electrons which possess the same velocity . in this case",
    ", the parameter @xmath61 in the model ( 1 ) has some certain value , so that the results obtained in the previous sections are directly applicable .",
    "the spikes in @xmath0 mean a drastic increase of the dc - conductivity occurring at a very weak amplitude of the ac electric field .",
    "the frequency of the ac field should be close to one of the spike frequencies .",
    "the effect is especially pronounced for the 1st spike i.e. when @xmath328 $ ] .",
    "if the electron motion takes place in a semiconductor @xcite , then the velocity in the @xmath329-direction is necessarily _ statistically distributed_. the same concerns the parameter @xmath61 then .",
    "this might seem to smear the effect : cf .",
    "@xcite where the _ conventional _ scenario of the onset of global chaos was exploited",
    ". however , in the case of the zero - dispersion  scenario suggested in our paper , it typically should not be so .",
    "indeed , a statistical distribution of the velocity typically decreases _ exponentially sharply _ as the velocity exceeds some characteristic value @xmath330 : for high temperature @xmath331 , the boltzmann distribution of energy is relevant and , therefore , @xmath332 ; for low temperatures , the fermi distribution is relevant and , therefore , @xmath333 where @xmath334 is the fermi energy . on the other hand , in the range of small @xmath61 ,",
    "the function @xmath335 does not significantly change even if @xmath61 changes by a few times .",
    "hence , if @xmath336 ( where @xmath337 denotes the @xmath61 value corresponding to @xmath330 ) , then the frequency @xmath270 of the partial ( i.e. for a given value of @xmath338 ) 1st - order spike is nearly the same for most of the velocities in the relevant range @xmath339 , and it is approximately equal to @xmath340 $ ] .",
    "similarly , @xmath341 .",
    "thus , as a function of @xmath15 for fixed @xmath342 , the dc - conductivity should have a sharp maximum for @xmath343 .",
    "if the parameter @xmath61 is time - dependent ( e.g. if the external magnetic field has an ac component or / and there is an ac electric force perpendicular to the @xmath323-direction ) , then the applications may be similar , with the only difference that the values of @xmath15 and @xmath14 in the minima of the main spikes differ from those for the additive perturbation , see fig .",
    "13 and the related discussion .",
    "the results of the present paper may also be of direct relevance for a pendulum spinning about its vertical axis @xcite , provided the friction is small . the periodic driving may be easily introduced mechanically , or electrically if the pendulum is electrically charged , or magnetically if the pendulum includes a ferromagnetic material .    finally , we mention in this subsection that potentials similar to @xmath90 ( 1 ) , i.e. periodic potentials with two different - height barriers per period , may readily be generated for cold atoms by means of optical lattices @xcite . the dissipation may be suppressed by means of the detuning from the atomic resonance @xcite .",
    "then the results of our paper are also of direct relevance to such systems .      consider the noise - induced escape over a potential barrier in the presence of a non - adiabatic periodic driving .",
    "for a moderately weak damping , such a driving decreases the activation barrier due to the resonant pushing the system in the range of resonant energies @xcite .",
    "if the damping is even smaller , the decrease of the activation barrier becomes larger , due , however , to a different mechanism , typically related to the chaotic layer associated with the separatrix of the unperturbed system @xcite .",
    "the lower energy boundary of the layer is smaller than the potential barrier energy , so it is sufficient that the noise pulls the system right to this boundary ( rather than to the very top of the potential barrier ) , after which the system may escape over the barrier purely dynamically .",
    "if the eigenfrequency as a function of the energy possesses a local maximum , then the effect may be even more pronounced @xcite : the decrease of the activation barrier may become comparable to the potential barrier at unusually small amplitudes of the driving , provided the driving frequency is close to the extremal eigenfrequency .",
    "one of the main mechanisms of the latter effect is closely related to phenomena discussed in the present paper . in the case of escape over",
    "_ two _ barriers of different heights , the effect should become even more pronounced due to the mechanism responsible for the spikes of @xmath0 studied in the present paper . if the potential is periodic , e.g. like in optical lattices @xcite , the effect may lead to a drastic acceleration of the spatial diffusion .      our results may be applied to the stochastic web formation @xcite .",
    "if a harmonic oscillator is perturbed by a plane wave whose frequency is equal to the oscillator eigenfrequency or its multiple , then the perturbation plays two roles @xcite . on one hand , due to the resonance with the oscillator",
    ", it transforms the structure of the phase space of the oscillator , leading to an infinite number of cells divided by a unique separatrix .",
    "it has the form of a web of an infinite radius . on the other hand , the perturbation dresses \" this separatrix by an exponentially narrow chaotic layer ( it is sometimes called stochastic  layer ) .",
    "such a web - like layer is called _",
    "stochastic web_. it may lead to chaotic transport of the system for rather long distances both in coordinate and in energy .    in case when either the resonance is not exact or / and the unperturbed oscillator possesses some nonlinearity , the perturbation generates _ many _ separatrices embedded into each other @xcite rather than one single infinite web - like separatrix .",
    "then a significant chaotic transport in energy may arise only if the magnitude of the perturbation exceeds some critical value corresponding to the overlap of chaotic layers associated , at least , with two neighbouring separatrices . and",
    ", still , the transport in energy remains limited since the width of the chaotic layer around each separatrix sharply decreases as the energy increases .",
    "it can be shown @xcite that some types of additional time - periodic perturbation lead to a low - frequency dipole perturbation of the resonance system ( cf .",
    "the paragraph preceding eq .",
    "the structure of separatrices in the reduced system possesses properties similar to that of the system considered in the present paper .",
    "indeed , in the region between the separatrices , the resonance system performs regular oscillations , and the frequency of such oscillations , as function of the value of the resonance hamiltonian , is equal to zero at each of the separatrices .",
    "thus , it necessarily possesses a local maximum between energies corresponding to any two neighbouring separatrices , like in the case considered in the present paper .",
    "if the additional perturbation has an optimal frequency related to one of these local maxima , then the overlap of chaotic layers associated with neighbouring separatrices is greatly facilitated , similarly to the case considered in the present paper .",
    "moreover , the local maximum of the eigenfrequency changes from pair to pair of separatrices _ weakly _ , so that if the magnitude of the auxiliary perturbation exceeds the critical value even slightly the simultaneous overlap between _ many _",
    "chaotic layers may occur .",
    "then , the distance of the chaotic transport in energy greatly increases .",
    "similar applications are relevant for the so called homogeneous ( sometimes called periodic ) stochastic webs @xcite and many other web - like stochastic structures @xcite .    beside classical systems",
    ", stochastic webs may arise in quantum systems too .",
    "it was recently demonstrated , both theoretically @xcite and experimentally @xcite , that the stochastic web may play a crucial role in quantum electron transport in semiconductor superlattices subjected to stationary electric and magnetic fields . due to the spatial periodicity with a period of about a few nanometers ,",
    "the system possesses narrow minibands in the electron spectrum .",
    "it turns out that the description of the electron transport in the lowest miniband may be approximated by the model of a classical harmonic oscillator driven by a plane wave .",
    "the role of the harmonic oscillator is played by the cyclotron motion while the wave arises due to the interplay between the cyclotron motion and bloch oscillations .",
    "if the cyclotron and bloch frequencies are commensurate , then the phase space of such a system is threaded by a stochastic web .",
    "this gives rise to the delocalization of electron orbits , that leads in turn to a strong increase of the conductivity @xcite .",
    "however , this effect occurs only when the ratio between the electric and magnetic fields lies in the _ exponentially narrow _ regions corresponding to nearly integer ratios between the bloch and cyclotron frequencies .",
    "the results of the present work suggest a method for a significant increase of the width of the relevant regions .",
    "if the cyclotron and bloch frequencies are not exactly commensurate , then the stochastic web does not arise : rather a set of embedded separatrices arises provided the effective wave amplitude is sufficiently large . as discussed in the previous paragraph ,",
    "even a rather weak time - periodic driving @xcite of the optimal frequency may significantly increase the area of the phase space involved in the chaotic transport .",
    "this may provide for an effective control of the electron transport in such a system and may be used for developing electronic devices that exploit the intrinsic sensitivity of chaos ( cf .",
    "a similar effect may be used also to control transmission through other periodic structures , e.g. ultra - cold atoms in optical lattices @xcite and photonic crystals @xcite .",
    "we have developed a new _ general approach _ for the treatment of separatrix chaos .",
    "this has allowed us to create a self - contained theory for the drastic facilitation of the global chaos onset between adjacent separatrices of a i d hamiltonian system subject to a time - periodic perturbation .",
    "both the new approach and the theory of the facilitation are closely interwoven in our paper but , at the same time , each of these two items is relevant even on its own .",
    "that is why we summarize them separately .",
    "* i. * _ the new approach for separatrix chaos_.    the approach is based on the separatrix map analysis which uses the characteristic property of the dependence of the frequency of eigenoscillation on energy in the vicinity of a separatrix : the frequency keeps nearly a _ constant _ value even if the deviation of the energy from the separatrix _ strongly varies _ within a given scale of the deviation . due to this",
    ", the separatrix map evolves along the major part of the chaotic trajectory in _ regular - like _ way .",
    "the deviation of the chaotic trajectory from the separatrix may vary along the regular - like parts of the trajectory in a much wider range than along the irregular parts .    in the case of resonant perturbation",
    ", we match the separatrix map analysis and the resonant hamiltonian approximation .",
    "this allows us in particular to find the boundaries of the chaotic layers in the _ phase space _ , which well agrees with computer simulations ( fig .",
    "the latter theory has been successfully applied by us to the problem of the global chaos onset in the double - separatrix case , which is summarized in the item ii below .",
    "applications _ and _ generalizations _ of the approach include in particular the following .",
    "* it may be applied to the conventional _ single - separatrix _ case .",
    "in particular , our theory predicts that the _ maximal width _ of the separatrix chaotic layer in energy is typically @xmath344 , in contrast with former theories @xcite which assume that the maximal width is @xmath291 . * it allows to analyze the _ transport _ within the layer . *",
    "it may be generalized for a _ non - resonant _ perturbation and for a _ higher _ dimension .",
    "* ii . * _ the facilitation of the global chaos onset .",
    "_    we have considered in details the characteristic example of a hamiltonian system possessing _ two or more separatrices _ , subject to a time - periodic perturbation .",
    "the frequency @xmath3 of oscillation of the unperturbed motion necessarily possesses a _",
    "local maximum _ @xmath16 as a function of energy @xmath10 in the range between the separatrices .",
    "it is smaller than the frequency @xmath345 of eigenoscillation in the stable state of the hamiltonian system by a factor    @xmath346    where @xmath347 is the difference of the separatrices energies , while @xmath348 is the difference between the upper separatrix energy and the stable state energy .",
    "if @xmath349 , the function @xmath7 is close to @xmath16 for most of the energy range between the separatrices : in the asymptotic limit @xmath57 , @xmath7 approaches a _ rectangular _ form . besides , the amplitude @xmath101 of the @xmath36th fourier harmonic of the oscillation asymptotically approaches a _",
    "non - small _ constant value in the whole energy range between separatrices .",
    "these two properties are responsible for most of the characteristic features of the global chaos onset in between the separatrices .",
    "the most striking one is a _ drastic facilitation _ of the global chaos onset when the perturbation frequency @xmath15 approaches @xmath16 or its multiples : the perturbation amplitude @xmath33 required for global chaos possesses , as a function of the perturbation frequency @xmath15 , deep spikes close to @xmath16 or its multiples .",
    "on the basis of the theory for the boundaries of the chaotic layers , we have developed a _ self - consistent _ asymptotic theory for the _ spikes _ in the vicinity of the minima . in particular , the _ explicit _ asymptotic expressions for the very minima are given in eqs .",
    "( 52 ) and ( 55 ) .",
    "the minimal amplitude @xmath33 is smaller than the typical @xmath33 for @xmath15 beyond the close vicinity of @xmath16 by a factor @xmath350 .",
    "the theory well agrees with the simulation results",
    ".    we have also found the mechanisms responsible for the spike wings ( figs .",
    "the theory well fits the simulations ( fig .",
    "the asymptotic shape of the spike is _ universal _ : it is described by eq .",
    "( 67 ) ( fig .",
    "the facilitation of the global chaos onset may have the following _ applications _ in particular :    * drastic increase of the _ dc - conductivity _ of a 2d electron gas in a 1d magnetic superlattice ; * significant decrease of the _ activation barrier _ for noise - induced escape over double / multi - barrier structures , that may lead to a drastic acceleration of the _ diffusion _ in periodic structures ; * strong facilitation of the _ stochastic web _ formation .",
    "the work was partly supported by intas grants 97 - 574 and 00 - 00867 , by the convention between the institute of semiconductor physics and pisa university for 2005 - 2007 , and by the ictp program for short - term visits .",
    "we are grateful to d. escande , j. meiss and g. zaslavsky for discussions .",
    "sms and rm acknowledge the hospitality of pisa university and institute of semiconductor physics respectively .",
    "the chaotic layers of the system ( 2 ) associated with the separatrices of the unperturbed system ( 1 ) are described here by means of the separatrix map . to derive the map ,",
    "we follow the method described in @xcite , but the analysis of the map significantly differs from existing ones @xcite . it constitutes the method allowing to calculate chaotic layer boundaries in the _ phase space _ ( rather than just in energy ) .",
    "it also allows to quantitatively describe the _ transport _ within the layer in a manner different from existing ones ( cf . @xcite and references therein ) .",
    "the typical function @xmath351 for the trajectory close to the inner separatrix ( the separatrix corresponding to the lower potential barrier ) is shown in fig .",
    "one can resolve pulses in @xmath351 .",
    "each of them consists of two approximately antisymmetric spikes @xcite .",
    "the pulses are separated by intervals during which @xmath352 is relatively small . generally speaking ,",
    "successive intervals differ of each other .",
    "let us introduce the pair of variables @xmath353 and @xmath354 :        the energy @xmath10 changes only during the pulses of @xmath351 and remains nearly unchanged during the intervals between the pulses , when @xmath357 is small @xcite .",
    "we assign numbers @xmath358 to the pulses and introduce the sequences of @xmath359 corresponding to initial instants of pulses @xmath360 .",
    "in such a way , we obtain the following map ( cf .",
    "@xcite ) :          \\1 . let us denote with @xmath365 the instant within the @xmath363th pulse when @xmath366 is equal to zero ( fig .",
    "the function @xmath367 is an odd function within the @xmath363th pulse and it is convenient to transform the cosine in the integrand in @xmath364 ( a2 ) as        \\2 .",
    "each pulse of @xmath366 contains one positive and one negative spike .",
    "the first spike can be either positive or negative . if @xmath10 changes during the given @xmath36th pulse so that its value at the end of the pulse is _ smaller _ than @xmath11 , then the first spikes of the @xmath363th and @xmath371st pulses have the _ same _ signs .",
    "on the contrary , if @xmath10 at the end of the @xmath363th pulse is _ larger _ than @xmath11 , then the first spikes of the @xmath363th and @xmath371st pulses have _ opposite _ signs .",
    "note that fig .",
    "14 corresponds to the case when the energy remains above @xmath11 during the whole interval shown in the figure .",
    "this obviously affects the sign of @xmath364 , and it may be explicitly accounted for in the map if we introduce a new discrete variable @xmath372 which characterizes the sign of @xmath366 at the beginning of a given @xmath363th pulse ,              the map similar to ( a5 ) was introduced for the first time in @xcite , and it is often called as the zaslavsky separatrix map . its mathematically rigorous derivation may be found e.g. in the recent major mathematical review @xcite .",
    "the latter review describes also generalizations of the zaslavsky map as well as other types of separatrix maps .",
    "the analysis presented below relates immediately to the zaslavsky map but it is hoped to be possible to generalize it for other types of the separatrix maps too .",
    "the variable @xmath164 introduced in ( a5 ) will be convenient for the further calculations since it does not depend on @xmath363 in the lowest - order approximation .",
    "a quantity like @xmath376 is sometimes called the _ separatrix split _ @xcite since it is conventionally assumed that the maximal deviation of energy on the chaotic trajectory from the separatrix energy is of the order of @xmath170 @xcite .",
    "though we shall also use this term , we emphasize that the maximal deviation may be much larger .",
    "dynamical chaos appears in the separatrix map ( a5 ) because @xmath377 .",
    "various heuristic criteria were suggested for the estimate of the chaotic layer width in energy @xcite .",
    "frequencies relevant to our problem are much smaller than the reciprocal width of the spikes of @xmath351 . for such frequencies ,",
    "all these criteria @xcite give :        the estimate ( a6 ) was used in our earlier theory @xcite .",
    "but we found later that , for the case of small @xmath15 , the aforementioned criteria were _ insufficient _ , so that the estimate ( a6 ) was incorrect @xcite ( cf . also ) .",
    "moreover , to search a uniform width of the layer is incorrect in cases like ours , where the width strongly depends on the angle . at the same time ,",
    "the _ lowest - order _",
    "formulas for the spike minimum @xmath221 are not affected by this , so that the results of @xcite ( with only the lowest - order formulas ) are correct .",
    "still , the higher - order corrections ( quite significant for @xmath56 if @xmath61 is moderately small ) would be incorrect if they were calculated on the basis of the estimate ( a6 ) .",
    "besides , the paper @xcite did not address the intriguing question : why does even a small excess of @xmath14 over @xmath0 result in the onset of chaos in a large part of the phase space between the separatrices , despite the fact that the width of the chaotic layers associated with the nonlinear resonances is _ exponentially small _ for @xmath379 ?",
    "the analysis of the separatrix map presented below resolves these important problems .    in the adiabatic limit @xmath380",
    ", the excess of the upper boundary @xmath381 of the lower layer over the lower barrier @xmath11 does not depend on angle and equals @xmath382 @xcite ( cf . also ) . but @xmath15 relevant for the spike of @xmath0 can not be considered as an adiabatic frequency , despite its smallness , because it is close to @xmath16 or to its multiple while all energies at the boundary lie in the range where the eigenfrequency is also close to @xmath16 :          let us explicitly evaluate @xmath164 .",
    "given that the energy is close to @xmath11 , the velocity @xmath367 in @xmath164 ( a5 ) may be replaced by the corresponding velocity along the separatrix associated with the lower barrier , @xmath384 , while the upper limit in the integral may be replaced by infinity . besides , in the asymptotic limit @xmath57 , the interval between spikes within the pulse becomes infinitely long @xcite and , therefore , only short ( @xmath385 ) intervals corresponding to the spikes contribute to the integral in @xmath164 ( a5 ) . in the scale @xmath386",
    ", they may be considered just as two instants  :          in the derivation of the first equality in ( a9 ) , we have also taken into account that the function @xmath389 is odd . in the derivation of the second equality in ( a9 ) , we have taken into account that the right turning point of the relevant separatrix is the top of the lower barrier and the distance between this point and the left turning point of the separatrix approaches @xmath127 in the limit @xmath57 .            where the instant @xmath393 corresponds to the turning point of the separatrix to the left from the lower barrier , i.e. @xmath394 while @xmath395 for all @xmath396 .",
    "the dependence @xmath397 by eq .",
    "( a11 ) is shown for @xmath161 in fig .",
    "for small frequencies , the asymptotic formula ( a9 ) well fits the formula ( a11 ) .",
    "consider the _ dynamics _ of the map ( a5 ) , when @xmath15 is close to the spikes minima : @xmath398 where @xmath257 while @xmath399 .",
    "let the energy at the step @xmath400 be equal to @xmath11 .",
    "the trajectory passing through the state with this energy is chaotic since @xmath401 diverges as @xmath402 and , therefore , the angle @xmath403 is not correlated with the angle on the previous step @xmath404 .",
    "the quantity @xmath405 is not correlated with @xmath406 either .",
    "thus , @xmath407 may take any value in the range @xmath408 $ ] and @xmath405 may equally take the values 1 or -1 .",
    "therefore , the energy may change on the next step by an arbitrary value in the interval @xmath409 $ ] .",
    "thus , @xmath410 may have a positive value @xmath411 @xcite .",
    "then , the approximate equality @xmath412 holds , provided the value of @xmath14 is from the relevant range .",
    "allowing for this and recalling that we are interested only in those realizations of the map such that @xmath413 , the relevant realization of the map @xmath414 may be written as :      one may expect that the further evolution of the map will approximately follow , for some time , the trajectory of the system ( 4 ) with the initial energy @xmath416 ( a12 ) , and with an arbitrary @xmath403 and initial slow angle @xmath120 somehow related to @xmath417 .",
    "let us prove this explicitly .",
    "consider two subsequent iterations of the map ( a5 ) : @xmath418 and @xmath419 with an arbitrary @xmath420 . while doing this , we shall assume the validity of ( a7 ) ( it will be clarified below when this is true ) from which it follows that : ( i ) @xmath421 , ( ii ) @xmath422 .",
    "it will follow from the results that the neglected corrections are small in comparison with the characteristic scales of the variation of @xmath10 and @xmath423 ( cf .",
    "the conventional treatment of the nonlinear resonance dynamics @xcite ) . besides",
    ", it follows from ( a5 ) that , while the energy remains above the barrier energy , @xmath424 oscillates , so that @xmath425 and @xmath426 .",
    "then ,              let us ( i ) use for @xmath164 the asymptotic formula ( a10 ) , ( ii ) take into account that the increase of @xmath363 by 1 corresponds to the increase of time by @xmath436 , and ( iii ) transform from the variables @xmath437 to the variables @xmath438 .",
    "equations ( a15 ) reduce then to :    @xmath439}\\sin(\\tilde{\\psi } ) , \\nonumber \\\\ & & \\frac{{\\rm d}\\tilde{\\psi}}{{\\rm d}t}= n\\omega-\\omega_f , \\\\ & & \\tilde{\\psi}\\equiv n\\pi\\frac{1-\\sigma_0}{2}-\\tilde{\\varphi } , \\quad\\quad n\\equiv 2j-1 .",
    "\\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    equations ( a16 ) are identical to the equations of motion of the system ( 4 ) in the lowest - order approximation , i.e. to the equations ( 14 ) where @xmath101 is replaced by its asymptotic value ( 12 ) and the last term in the right - hand part of the second equation is neglected , being of higher order in comparison with the term @xmath440 .",
